story:
Once upon a time, in a lush and vibrant forest in the heart of Brazil, there lived a curious and adventurous little boy named João. João was known throughout the village for his boundless energy and insatiable curiosity. He spent his days exploring the forest, discovering new creatures, and learning about the world around him.

One day, as João was wandering through the forest, he stumbled upon a beautiful and mysterious bird with feathers of every color imaginable. The bird was perched upon a branch, singing a song so enchanting that João couldn't help but be drawn to it.

"Hello, little bird," said João, approaching the bird slowly so as not to startle it. "I have never seen a bird quite like you before. Where do you come from?"

The bird looked down at João and tilted its head quizzically. "I come from the mythical land of Tupa, where the sun meets the earth and all creatures live in harmony," the bird replied.

João's eyes widened with excitement. "Tupa! I have heard stories of that place, but I never believed it was real. Can you take me there?"

The bird considered João's request for a moment before nodding its head. "Very well, I will take you to Tupa. But you must promise me one thing: you must never speak a word while we are there, for the language of Tupa is one of silence and understanding."

João eagerly agreed, and the bird spread its wings wide and took to the sky, with João clinging tightly to its back. They soared over the forest canopy, higher and higher until they reached the edge of the world, where the sky met the earth in a blaze of golden light.

There, spread out before them, was the magical land of Tupa. It was a place unlike anything João had ever seen before. The trees were taller and more majestic than any he had ever seen, and the air was filled with the sound of a thousand different birds singing in harmony.

João and the bird flew over fields of flowers that seemed to stretch on forever, and over rivers that shimmered with gold and silver. They saw creatures of all shapes and sizes, from tiny insects to enormous beasts, but all living together in harmony, just as the bird had said.

As they flew, João marveled at the beauty of Tupa, but he remembered his promise to the bird and remained silent. He knew that this was a place of silence and understanding, and that words were not necessary here.

Finally, as the sun began to set, the bird brought João to a beautiful grove, filled with trees that seemed to glow from within. There, surrounded by the most beautiful flowers he had ever seen, was a magnificent palace made of crystal and gold.

"This is the palace of Tupa," the bird said softly. "You must enter alone, and remember: do not speak a word."

João nodded, and the bird flew away, leaving him to explore the palace on his own. João wandered through the halls, marveling at the treasures that were hidden within. He saw paintings of the most beautiful landscapes he had ever seen, and sculptures of creatures so lifelike that he felt as though they might come to life at any moment.

As he explored, he came upon a chamber at the heart of the palace. Inside, he saw a figure seated upon a throne of gold. It was a beautiful woman, with skin the color of copper and hair that seemed to catch the light and shine like the stars.

João approached the figure on tiptoe, not wanting to disturb her. But as he drew near, she opened her eyes and looked at him. Her eyes were as dark as the night sky, but they seemed to hold all the secrets of the universe.

"Who are you, child?" she asked, her voice soft and gentle.

João opened his mouth to speak, but then remembered his promise to the bird. He looked at the figure, his eyes pleading, and shrugged his shoulders.

The figure smiled, and gestured for him to come closer. "You are wise to remain silent, child," she said. "For the language of Tupa is one of silence and understanding."

She took his hand and led him to a window that looked out over the land of Tupa. "This is a place of beauty and wonder," she said. "But it is also a place of fragile balance.
